quiz.title: Quiz S01: Shell Fundamentals
quiz.description: Formative quiz for Seminar 01 - Shell Fundamentals

questions.text: What does the pwd command display?

answers.feedback: Processes are displayed with ps or top.
Current user is displayed with whoami.
Correct! pwd = Print Working Directory.
Passwords are never displayed in plain text in Linux.

questions.text: Which directory contains system configuration files?

answers.feedback: /home contains user directories.
Correct! /etc contains system configurations.
/bin contains basic executables.
/tmp is for temporary files.

questions.text: What is the difference between shell and terminal?

answers.feedback: They are not synonyms - they have different roles.

answers.text: The shell is the program that interprets commands, the terminal is the interface
answers.feedback: Correct! The shell (bash) interprets, the terminal is the graphical interface.

answers.text: The terminal interprets commands, the shell is the window
answers.feedback: It's the other way round - the shell interprets commands.
There are clear functional differences.
Relative paths do not start with /.
Correct! It starts with / (root), so it's absolute.
Symbolic paths are links, not a type of path.
The concept of virtual path doesn't exist in Linux.

questions.text: If I set VAR='test' without export and start a subshell, what will echo $VAR display in the subshell?

answers.feedback: Local variables are not visible in subprocesses.
Correct! Without export, the variable is not in the environment.
It's not an error, just an empty result.
Without single quotes, $VAR expands.

questions.text: What command creates the directory structure /project/src/main/java if it doesn't exist?

answers.feedback: Without -p, mkdir fails if parents don't exist.
Correct! -p (parents) creates all necessary directories.
-r is not a valid option for mkdir.
--create is not a valid option for mkdir.

questions.text: You just modified ~/.bashrc. What command applies the changes in the current session?

answers.feedback: restart is not a valid command in this context.
Correct! source (or .) executes the script in the current shell.
refresh is not a Bash command.
reload is not a standard Bash command.

questions.text: What files does the command: touch file{1,2,3}.txt create?

answers.feedback: Brace expansion expands before execution.
Correct! Brace expansion creates 3 separate files.
It doesn't concatenate - it creates separate files.
The syntax is valid - it's brace expansion.
Single quotes don't expand variables.
Correct! Single quotes keep everything literal.
The syntax is correct.
$NAME remains literal in single quotes.

questions.text: What does exit code 0 signify in Linux?

answers.feedback: Non-zero means error.
127 means command not found.
Correct! 0 = success in Unix convention.
1 or another non-zero code for permission errors.

questions.text: You want to copy all .log files from /var/log to ~/backup. Which command is correct?

answers.feedback: Missing * before .log - this matches nothing.
Correct! *.log matches all files ending in .log.
Single quotes prevent glob expansion - no pattern matching.
Missing dot - *log matches syslog, not just .log files.

questions.text: Compare: DIR='/home/user'; rm -rf $DIR/temp versus DIR=''; rm -rf $DIR/temp — what is the critical difference?

answers.feedback: The empty variable creates a dangerous path.
Correct! Empty $DIR makes $DIR/temp become /temp. Always quote and verify before rm -rf.
No syntax error - the command runs, which is the problem.
It does something dangerous - deletes /temp if it exists.
